Authors:
yanli Wang, Quan Lu, Cony Decock, Li Yongxia, Zhang
Xingyao
Title:
A survey of Cytospora and associated teleomorphs from Populus
spp. and Salix spp. in China, including C. davidiana sp. nov.
Keywords:
Cytospora canker. Phylogenetic species. Species diversity.
Taxonomy. Populus spp. and Salix spp.
Abstract:
Poplar and willow plantations are becoming more and more
widespread in China, in order to meet both national economic and
environmental needs. Concomitantly, several pathogens are emerging,
sometimes enhanced by climatic change and other human factors. Species
of Cytospora (or its associated teleomorph, Valsa) are well-known
pathogens on both poplar and willow, causing stem cankers and diebacks.
The aim of this study was to make a survey of Cytospora species and
associated teleomorphs occurring on Populus spp. and Salix spp. in
China. Morphology and phylogenetic inferences, based on the DNA sequence
data from the internal transcribed spacer region (ITS1, 5.8S rDNA and
ITS2) and partial Î²-tubulin gene, allowed identifying 6 species on
poplar and willow. Five species were identified to known taxa viz. C.
chrysosperma (teleomorph Valsa sordida), C. translucens (teleomorph
Leucostoma translucens), C. fugax (teleomorph Valsa salicina), C.
atrocirrhata, and C. kantschavelii. Cytospora davidiana sp. nov. on
poplar, characterized by typical torsellioid conidiomata, is described
as new. An additional Cytospora sp 1, forming a distinct clade in both
phylogenetic inferences, remains unnamed; the paucity of available
materials impeded a phenotypical characterization. Further sampling
efforts and molecular-based identification are needed still to improve
our understanding of the taxonomic diversity of Cytospora, their host
range and geographic distribution in China.
